awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Planning Flood Resilient Infrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Planners and engineers in municipalities and localities around the United States are increasingly challenged to develop more efficient and technologically sound methods for contending with severe disasters, such as wildfires, floods and natural disasters. In Houston, five 500-year floods have hit in the last five years according to current Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) flood risk designations. Every government from local to federal is challenged with building cities and communities resilient to changing environmental circumstances. This project investigates how local engineers, developers, industry representatives, and public officials involved in infrastructure development navigate these changing conditions in the development of flood mitigation plans. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project would enhance scientific understanding by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations invested in developing more effective methods for communicating science and the scientific method in disaster and flood mitigation planning. 
 
The research project investigates environmental impact and response at a central node in the oil and gas industry, Houston, Texas. The major metropolitan city and its industrial infrastructure is uniquely vulnerable to sea level rise, coastal erosion, and increasingly devastating storms. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) measures current sea level rise at the mouth of the Houston Ship Channel as higher than almost anywhere else in the world. The research will include twelve months of ethnographic fieldwork (including participant-observation and semi-structured interviews as well as mapping exercises) in Houston examining public and private sector stakeholders roles in flood infrastructure planning. As threats of intensified flooding loom, how do these stakeholders negotiate entangled fears of social, economic, and environmental disasters? Through qualitative and spatial analysis of ethnographic and archival evidence of flood infrastructure preparations, this research explores the dichotomy between symbolism and expertise where scientific knowledge, public narrative, and vested interest may influence sharply different approaches in infrastructural planning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Doctoral Dissertation Research: Planning Flood Resilient Infrastructure project followed public and private sector stakeholders negotiating flood infrastructure plans in and around Houston amidst a series of disastrous flooding events including Hurricane Harvey. The latest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reports attributed more and worse rain events to climate change, but locally attribution was fraught. Through eighteen months of ethnographic observations between June of 2018 and October of 2020, 46 in depth semi-structured interviews, and extensive archival research, this project found that the afterlife of decades of misinformation by the oil and gas industry and contemporary economic dependence on confidence in that industry could be observed in practices of avoidance understood through the anthropological concept of taboo. Through observed acts of avoidance, misinformation is understood as material, situated in space and time, between people and through material processes and institutions.  This project found this more structural approach to what is often understood under the umbrella of climate denial revealed the way different forms of misinformation build upon each other from tobacco industry framed denial of industrial harm to vaccine refusal, frayed relationships to facts and fact producing institutions are connected through human relationships and choices, observable in the historical record and through ethnographic investigation. In simpler terms, misinformation is not just a Facebook problem. This project focused on the political life of scientific evidence and found that some of the government agents most willing to act on climate change evidence, in this case National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration?s Atlas 14 report, did not want to speak the words ?climate change? and were ideologically opposed to those who championed them. Amongst the stakeholders observed ethnographically in this project, corruption was more a determinant of climate inaction than political ideology. Further, the benefit-cost ratio that drives all federal infrastructure projects intersected with historic redlining?s discounting of property values according to race to make it so present day flood infrastructure choices amplify racial disparities built over time without necessarily being based on personal racial animosity. The researcher certainly observed personal racism and climate denial, but found that federal policies and local institutions, relationships and infrastructure drove the scale of negative impacts associated with personal ideologies. This project concluded that new methods of analysis and governance are needed to measure life, loss and damage differently so that flood waters don?t continue to be a medium for amplifying systemic inequality. This project observed the beginnings of those efforts at the local level from civil society based initiatives to Harris County?s new prioritization framework and the establishment of the Community Flood Resilience Task Force. The researcher shared these findings to relevant audiences by presenting at the American Anthropological Association, the Natural Hazards Center Researchers Workshop and the Kinder Institute for Urban Research at Rice University and through individual conversations at the local level. The researcher is working on related peer-reviewed publications leading to a book manuscript published as soon as early 2023.
